Description: I) INVEST IN AND SUPPORT HIGH-PRIORITY ACTIONS THAT ADDRESS KEY LIMITING FACTORS TO SALMON AND STEELHEAD PRODUCTION AND HABITAT. FOCUS ON RIPARIAN RESTORATION AND OTHER PROJECTS THAT PROVIDE LASTING IMPROVEMENTS TO ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION AND PROCESS. II) INVEST IN AND MANAGE GRANTS FOR LARGE-SCALE RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES. COORDINATE INVESTMENTS TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE SALMONID LIMITING FACTORS, INCLUDING CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS TO VULNERABLE SALMON AND STEELHEAD SPECIES. III) MONITOR SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS. CONDUCT LARGE-SCALE EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING. SUPPORT TRACKING AND REPORTING OF ECOLOGICAL OUTCOMES ASSOCIATED WITH COORDINATED INVESTMENTS IN SALMON RECOVERY.

THE PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED TO MEET U.S. OBLIGATIONS FOR JOINT ENHANCEMENT EFFORTS ON THE TRANSBOUNDARY RIVERS AS SPECIFIED IN THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY. THE PROGRAM INVOLVES SUPPLEMENTING NUMBER OF SOCKEYE AVAILABLE TO FISHERMEN BY INCREASING FRY PRODUCTION FROM SEVERAL TRANSBOUNDARY LAKES THROUGH HATCHERY INCUBATION IN THE U.S. THE PROGRAM UTILIZES OTOLITH MASS MARKING TO IDENTIFY ENHANCED FISH TO MONITOR THE PROGRAM AND TO AID IN THE MANAGEMENT OF FISHERIES TARGETING THE TRANSBOUNDARY RIVER STOCKS.

TOGETHER WITH STATE MATCHING FUNDS, WASHINGTON'S PCSRF AND IIJA AWARD WILL FUND PROJECTS AND ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN NOAA-APPROVED RECOVERY PLANS AND THAT UPHOLD TREATY RIGHTS. THE 120 HIGH-PRIORITY, SITE-BASED PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS LIMITING FACTORS AND PROTECT OR RESTORE HABITAT STATEWIDE. HATCHERY AND HARVEST REFORM ACTIONS WILL COMPLEMENT THE HABITAT PROJECTS BY IMPROVING FITNESS OF WILD FISH AND ADDRESSING HATCHERY OPERATIONS THAT LIMIT THE PRODUCTIVITY OF LISTED POPULATIONS AND NON-LISTED POPULATIONS ESSENTIAL FOR EXERCISE OF TRIBAL TREATY RIGHTS. WASHINGTON'S ESTABLISHED MULTI-TIERED MONITORING PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SALMON HABITAT PROJECTS AND MEASURE PROGRESS TOWARD RECOVERY. MONITORING OUTCOMES INCLUDE DATA AND FINDINGS THAT HELP DETERMINE IF FUNDS ARE WELL-INVESTED, PRODUCE DESIRED RESULTS, AND SUPPORT WASHINGTON'S ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH.

THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM TRIBAL RESEARCH AND RESTORATION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO ACHIEVE RESTORATION EFFORTS BY REBUILDING SALMON POPULATIONS AND BRINGING RELIEF TO THE RESOURCE-DEPENDENT PEOPLE LIVING IN THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM REGION. RESEARCH EFFORTS ARE MADE TO MAKE RAPID PROGRESS IN UNDERSTANDING AND RECOVERING FROM RECENT SALMON DECLINES WHICH INFLICT EXTREME STRESS AND HARDSHIP ON THE RESIDENTS OF THE REGION.

IDAHO PROGRAM OBJECTIVES: PRIORITY ONE. HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS SELECTED FOR FUNDING IN THE IDAHO PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS FACTORS LIMITING ABUNDANCE AND PRODUCTIVITY OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA)-LISTED PACIFIC SALMONIDS IN PRIORITY SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT. LIMITING FACTORS FOR EACH POPULATION IN EACH MAJOR POPULATION GROUP OF THE SNAKE RIVER STEELHEAD DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) AND/OR SPRING/SUMMER CHINOOK SALMON AND SOCKEYE SALMON EVOLUTIONARILY SIGNIFICANT UNITS (ESU), ARE PROVIDED IN TABLE 5 OF THIS DOCUMENT. THE IDAHO PROGRAM (IDAHO RECOVERY PLAN) IS ALIGNED WITH THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS) 2017 ESA RECOVERY PLAN FOR IDAHO SNAKE RIVER SPRING/SUMMER CHINOOK SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA) AND SNAKE RIVER STEELHEAD (ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND THE NMFS 2015 RECOVERY PLAN FOR SNAKE RIVER SOCKEYE SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS NERKA).  PRIORITY TWO. THE IDAHO PROGRAM WILL CONSIDER FUNDING PROJECTS THAT WILL PROVIDE EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING OF HABITAT ACTIONS

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE AND IMPROVE HABITAT AND WATERSHED PROCESSES FOR SALMONIDS AND OTHER IMPORTANT ANADROMOUS SPECIES THAT WERE ONCE ABUNDANT IN THE RIVERS OF THE TRIBAL ANCESTRAL HOMELAND. THE ABUNDANT RETURN OF THESE FISH POPULATIONS WILL CREATE THE OPPORTUNITY TO FISH IN A MANNER THAT HONORS AND MAINTAINS TRIBAL CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND WILL EVENTUALLY ALLOW FOR SUBSISTENCE FISHING. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, CTCLUSI WILL CONTINUE ITS WORK WITH COLLABORATIVE PARTNERS TO UNDERTAKE THE WAITE RANCH TIDAL WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECT IN THE LOWER SIUSLAW RIVER ESTUARY, WHERE COHO FISHERIES WERE HISTORICALLY VITAL TO THE TRIBES.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE SHOSHONE-BANNOCK TRIBES (SBT) CULTURAL AND SUBSISTENCE FISHERY MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (CSFMMP) IS TO PROVIDE TREATY-RESERVED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES TO TRIBAL MEMBERS, WHILE MANAGING FISHERY IMPACTS AND TRIBAL HARVEST ACCORDING TO THE SBT'S TRIBAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS (TRMPS) FOR THE SALMON AND GRANDE RONDE/IMNAHA RIVER BASINS.  WITH THE SUPPORT OF THE PACIFIC COAST SALMON RECOVERY FUND (PCSRF), THE CSFMMP WILL PARTICIPATE IN FISHERY FORECASTING AND IN-SEASON MANAGEMENT OF TRIBAL FISHERIES ON SNAKE RIVER SPRING/SUMMER CHINOOK SALMON. THE SBT WILL SET FISHING REGULATIONS, GUIDELINES, AND SEASONS; AND COORDINATE THESE ACTIVITIES WITH TRIBAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL CO-MANAGERS. IN-SEASON CREEL SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO MONITOR AND ESTIMATE TRIBAL CATCH BY FISHERY MANAGEMENT AREA (POPULATION), ALLOWING FOR THE EVALUATION AND MANAGEMENT OF TRIBAL HARVEST IMPACTS.

THE COW CREEK BAND OF UMPQUA TRIBE OF INDIANS OWNS A WORKING CATTLE RANCH ON THE MAINSTEM ROGUE RIVER IN JACKSON COUNTY NEAR CENTRAL POINT, OREGON. A PORTION OF THE BANK IS ACTIVELY ERODING INTO A SIDE CHANNEL OF THE ROGUE RIVER. TRIBAL STAFF HAVE IDENTIFIED THIS AS A RESTORATION PROJECT THAT WILL PROTECT RANCHLANDS VITAL TO THE TRIBE'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, AS WELL AS PROTECT AND ENHANCE IMPORTANT NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AND WATER QUALITY IN THE ROGUE RIVER. PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE THE COW CREEK BAND OF UMPQUA TRIBE OF INDIANS NATURAL RESOURCES DEPARTMENT (WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES PROGRAM), K-BAR RANCHES CORP. (TRIBALLY OWNED) AND THE TRIBE'S EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DEPARTMENT. FY 2022 PCSRF PRIORITY 1 FUNDS WILL BE USED TO COMPLETE PHASE 3 OF THE PROJECT: ON THE GROUND WORK, CONTINUING TO WORK WITH A PREVIOUSLY HIRED CONTRACTOR TO IMPLEMENT BANK RESTORATION AND INSTREAM STRUCTURES, PROJECT MANAGEMENT, AND FISCAL ADMINISTRATION. PCSRF FUNDS WILL BE USED TO TAKE THE PROJE

THE COWLITZ TRIBE'S CISPUS YELLOWJACKET PHASE 4 RESTORATION PROJECT TARGETS PACIFIC COASTAL SALMON RECOVERY FUND NOFO PRIORITY (1) BY IMPLEMENTING INSTREAM WORK AT THE PROJECT SITE THAT WILL INCREASE THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF SPAWNING, REARING AND ADULT HOLDING HABITAT ON SITE AND IN DOWNSTREAM REACHES FOR SALMON AND STEELHEAD, AS SPECIFIED IN THE 2010 LOWER COLUMBIA SALMON RECOVERY AND FISH & WILDLIFE SUBBASIN PLAN (RECOVERY PLAN).

THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT WORK AT ROWDY CREEK, A TRIBUTARY IN THE LOWER SMITH RIVER, HAS BEEN RECOGNIZED BY NOAA FISHERIES AS A TRIBUTARY OF PARTICULAR IMPORTANCE TO REBUILD THE COHO SALMON POPULATION IN THE SMITH RIVER BASIN (NOAA 2014). IT HAS ALSO BEEN DOCUMENTED BY NUMEROUS STUDIES AS SUPPORTING A VARIETY OF SPECIAL-STATUS SPECIES INCLUDING CHINOOK SALMON, COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD, COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, RAINBOW TROUT AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES, SUCH AS PACIFIC LAMPREY AND THE FOOTHILL YELLOW -LEGGED FROG (WALKLEY AND GARWOOD 2017, GARWOOD AND LARSON 2014, NOAA 2014, SRAC 2002, SCRIVEN 2001). SINCE 1972, ACCESS BY FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES TO 13 MILES OF COMBINED HABITAT ON ROWDY AND DOMINIE CREEKS HAS BEEN SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED OR COMPLETELY BLOCKED DUE TO THE PRESENCE AND OPERATION OF THE ROWDY CREEK FISH HATCHERY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO IMPLEMENT THE ROWDY CREEK AND DOMINIE CREEK FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENT PROJECT WHICH WILL REMOVE AND REPLACE HATCHERY INFRASTRUCTU

FUNDS WILL BE USED TO CONTINUE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE COQUILLE SUB-BASIN PLAN AND PCSRF PRIORITY ONE, ALLOWING THE TRIBE AND ITS MULTIPLE PARTNERS TO CONDUCT A RESTORATION AND MONITORING PROJECT WITHIN THE LOWER COQUILLE RIVER SUB-BASIN. THE PROJECT WILL SEEK TO IMPROVE LIMITING FACTORS FOR ESA LISTED OREGON COAST COHO (OC COHO) SALMON. THE PROJECT SPECIFICALLY SEEKS TO IMPROVE HABITATS THROUGH:          IMPROVEMENT OF SALMONID ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 9,800-ACRES CONTAINING 11.4-MILES OF COHO HABITAT AND 490-ACRES OF TIDAL WETLAND HABITAT.        REPLACE THE AGING COALEDO TIDE GATES WITH THREE SIDE-HINGED MUTED TIDAL REGULATOR (MTR) TIDE GATES.        IMPLEMENT A WATER MANAGEMENT PLAN (WMP) THAT SEASONALLY ADJUSTS WATER LEVELS.        COMPLETE CHANNEL ENHANCEMENTS WHICH INCLUDES REMOVAL OF UNNATURALLY HIGH SEDIMENT, REPLACING A FARM ACCESS BRIDGE, AND REMOVING A LOG BOOM IN LOWER BEAVER SLOUGH.        ENHANCING THE RIPARIAN BUFFER OF 2.5-MILES, WHICH WILL INCLUDE FENCING AND PLANTI

THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF PHASE III IS TO FOLLOW THE TWO PRIOR PILOT PROJECTS ABOVE TIDEWATER WITH A TIDEWATER HABITAT PILOT THAT CREATES ENHANCED AND COMPLEX CHANNEL HABITAT WITHIN 1.5 MILES OF A SEVEN MILE REACH OF THE MAINSTEM SILETZ RIVER ESTUARY CHANNEL. THIS WORK IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT JUVENILE SALMONIDS AND LAMPREY DURING KEY LIFE HISTORY PERIODS OF MAINSTEM HABITAT USE. THESE PERIODS OF HABITAT USE OCCUR DURING SPECIFIC SEASONS THAT VARY BY SPECIES AND LIFE HISTORY STAGE. THE TRIBE'S PHASE III PRIORITY SPECIES INCLUDE CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON, AND PACIFIC LAMPREY BUT THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT CHUM SALMON AND STEELHEAD TROUT AS WELL.

THE PUGET SOUND AND WASHINGTON COASTAL TREATY TRIBES PROPOSE USING THE FY 2022 PACIFIC COASTAL SALMON RECOVERY FUND (PCSRF) AWARD TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES THAT ADDRESS FACTORS LIMITING THE VIABILITY OF ESA-LISTED SALMONIDS; RESTORE AND PROTECT ANADROMOUS SALMONID HABITAT; CONDUCT ESSENTIAL SALMONID AND HABITAT MONITORING; AND ENGAGE IN OTHER ACTIVITIES CONSISTENT WITH THE CONGRESSIONAL AUTHORIZATION FOR THE PROGRAM. THE OVERARCHING INTENT OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO CONDUCT PROJECTS THAT WILL PROMOTE A MEANINGFUL EXPRESSION OF TREATY FISHING RIGHTS AND ADVANCE THE RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION OF ESA-LISTED AND NON-LISTED SALMON AND STEELHEAD.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE TRIBE CAPACITY TO REESTABLISH ITS ROLE AS STEWARDS OF THEIR ANCESTRAL TERRITORY BY CONDUCTING IMPACTFUL HABITAT RESTORATION  1.      LEARN SKILLS NECESSARY TO CONDUCT HABITAT RESTORATION THROUGH TRAININGS AND ATTENDANCE TO CONFERENCES.  2.      INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF ISSUES THROUGH COLLABORATIONS WITH PARTNERS  3.      PROMOTE TRIBAL INVOLVEMENT IN RESTORATION PRIORITIZATION AND PLANNING BY PARTICIPATING IN THE SALMON HABITAT RESTORATION PROGRAM (SHARP) AND EEL RIVER RESTORATION PLAN (EERP). 4.      ENSURE THE CAPACITY FOR THE WIYOT TRIBE TO GET FUNDING TO CONDUCT IMPACTFUL AND SIGNIFICANT HABITAT RESTORATION

THE COMMISSIONS 2022 SALMON AND STEELHEAD RECOVERY PROGRAM WILL ASSIST THE TRIBES IN CONDUCTING ORDERLY AND BIOLOGICALLY SOUND SALMON FISHERIES AND RECOVERY PROGRAMS BY PROVIDING CRITERIA FOR PROJECT PROPOSALS, PROJECT SELECTION, AND FUNDED PROJECTS.  THE COMMISSION SUPPORTS ITS' MEMBER TRIBES BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, INFORMATION SHARING, POLICY COORDINATION, AND GRANT ADMINISTRATION.  IT IS THE PURPOSE OF THE COMMISSION TO ADMINISTER AND MONITOR TRIBAL PROJECTS SELECTED TO RECEIVE FUNDING BY PROVIDING GUIDELINES FOR EFFICIENT DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT PROJECT FUNDING IN ACCORDANCE WITH PCSRF CRITERIA.  THE COMMISSION WILL ASSIST THE TRIBES BY COORDINATING SALMON RECOVERY EFFORTS AND BY FACILITATING EFFICIENT AND PRODUCTIVE USE OF PCSRF FUNDS.

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM'S ULTIMATE OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE EFFICIENT AND METICULOUS ADMINISTRATION OF THE 2022 PCSRF FUNDS FOR THE CRITFC TRIBES SO THAT TRIBAL PROJECTS RELATED TO SALMON HABITAT RESTORATION, SALMON STOCK ENHANCEMENT, SALMON RESEARCH, AND SUPPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES CAN BE IMPLEMENTED AND MONITORED IN A TIMELY MANNER. THESE PROJECTS WILL BE CONSISTENT WITH THE OVERALL 2022 PCSRF PROGRAM PRIORITIES OF IMPLEMENTING PROJECTS THAT PROVIDE DEMONSTRABLE AND MEASURABLE BENEFITS TO PACIFIC ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS (CHINOOK, COHO, CHUM, SOCKEYE, AND PINK SALMON AND STEELHEAD) AND THEIR HABITAT. THE PROPOSED PROJECTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE INCREASE IN CHINOOK STOCKS THROUGH THE RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF HABITAT IN AREAS WHERE THEY LIVE, WHICH WILL THEN ULTIMATELY, BENEFIT THE SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALE SURVIVAL LEVELS BY IMPROVING ITS PREY BASE. THE PROPOSED PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT SALMON POPULATIONS IMPORTANT TO THE EXERCISE OF TRIBAL TREATY FISHING RIGHTS AND WILL INCLUDE EFFORTS

THIS PROJECT WILL FOSTER THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF TRIBAL, STATE AND LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS TO RESTORE CHINOOK AND SOCKEYE IN THE UPPER COLUMBIA UPSTREAM OF CHIEF JOE DAM (CJD) AND GRAND COULEE DAM (GCD). FUNDING WILL ASSIST IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SALMON RESTORATION AND NATIVE SUBSISTENCE FISHING IN THE UPPER COLUMBIA RIVER AND ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) ASSIST IN RESTORATION OF NATIVE SUBSISTENCE FISHING IN AN AREA DEPRIVED OF SALMON FOR 80 YEARS. 2) SUPPORT THE OVERALL EFFORT TO IMPLEMENT PHASE 2 FEASIBILITY EVALUATIONS OF REINTRODUCTION OF SALMON TO THE BLOCKED AREA OF THE UPPER COLUMBIA BY EVALUATING THE OUTMIGRATION SURVIVAL AND TRAVEL TIME OF JUVENILE CHINOOK AND SOCKEYE. 3) DETERMINE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF TRAP AND HAUL EFFORTS AS A METHOD TO SUPPORT THE REINTRODUCTION OF SALMON IN THE BLOCKED AREA OF THE UPPER COLUMBIA, INCLUDING PROVIDING TRIBAL SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OPPORTUNITY AND JUVENILE FISH PRODUCTION. 4) RETURN SALMON TO NATIVE LANDS AND PEOPLE THAT HAVE B

ALASKA'S PROGRAM, THE ALASKA SUSTAINABLE SALMON FUND, SUPPORTS A MYRIAD OF PROJECTS NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY SALMON POPULATIONS AND TO PROTECT OR RESTORE THEIR HABITATS. THE PROJECTS, SELECTED THROUGH A RIGOROUS TECHNICAL REVIEW PROCESS, FOCUS ON PROACTIVE APPROACHES TO HABITAT CONSERVATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SALMON POPULATIONS UTILIZED IN SUBSISTENCE FISHERIES.

THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GATHER THE BASELINE DATA THAT IS NECESSARY TO INFORM THE FEASIBILITY OF SALMON REINTRODUCTION UPSTREAM OF CHIEF JOSEPH AND GRAND COULEE DAMS. THE DATA WILL REPLACE A NUMBER OF KEY ASSUMPTIONS MODELED WITHIN PHASE 1 SALMON REINTRODUCTION STUDIES (UCUT 2019), WITH EMPIRICAL DATA AND INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES SPECIFIC TO JUVENILE CHINOOK SALMON: 1. ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND TRAVEL TIME FROM THE MOUTH OF THE SANPOIL RIVER (RKM 987) AND KETTLE FALLS (RKM 1121) TO GRAND COULEE DAM (RKM 957).  2. ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND TRAVEL TIME FROM LITTLE FALLS DAM (RKM 1071), LONG LAKE DAM (RKM 1089), NINE MILE DAM (RKM 1127), AND LOWER HANGMAN CREEK (RKM 1141) TO GRAND COULEE DAM. 3. ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND TRAVEL TIME FROM GRAND COULEE DAM TO CHIEF JOSEPH DAM (RKM 877). 4. ASSESS NEAR-DAM BEHAVIOR AND ESTIMATE ROUTE-SPECIFIC PASSAGE SURVIVAL AT GRAND COULEE DAM. 5. ASSESS NEAR-DAM BEHAVIOR AND ESTIMATE ROUTE-SPECIFIC PASSAGE SURVIVAL AT CHIEF JOSEPH DAM.

EFFORTS FOCUS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOVERY PLANS THROUGH INVESTMENT IN AND SUPPORT OF HIGH-PRIORITY ACTIONS ADDRESSING KEY LIMITING FACTORS TO SALMON AND STEELHEAD PRODUCTION AND HABITAT, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RIPARIAN RESTORATION AND PROJECTS THAT RESULT IN LASTING IMPROVEMENTS TO ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION AND PROCESS; II) INVEST IN AND MANAGE GRANTS FOR LARGE-SCALE RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES THAT ADDRESS MULTIPLE SALMONID LIMITING FACTORS INCLUDING CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS TO VULNERABLE SALMON AND STEELHEAD SPECIES THROUGH COORDINATED INVESTMENTS; AND III) CONDUCT CRITICAL MONITORING OF SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS AND LARGE-SCALE EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING, SUPPORT TRACKING AND REPORTING OF ECOLOGICAL OUTCOMES ASSOCIATED WITH COORDINATED INVESTMENTS IN SALMON RECOVERY, AND ENABLE STRATEGIC ACTION PLANNING THAT ENSURES PRIORITIZATION AND ULTIMATE IMPLEMENTATION OF HIGH-IMPACT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION PROJECTS BENEFITTING SALMON AND STEELHEAD

THROUGH A COMPETITIVE ANNUAL GRANT PROCESS AND STATE CONTRACTING PRACTICES, CONTINUE CALIFORNIA'S RECOVERY EFFORTS ON BEHALF OF FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA)-LISTED ENDANGERED CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST (CCC) COHO SALMON AND SOUTHERN STEELHEAD POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS LISTED THREATENED SOUTHERN OREGON/NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COHO SALMON, NORTH AND CENTRAL STEELHEAD POPULATIONS, AND ENDANGERED/THREATENED CHINOOK. THIS INCLUDES NOAA'S SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT: CCC COHO AND THE CENTRAL VALLEY WINTER-RUN CHINOOK SALMON THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE PREY BASE FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO RE-ESTABLISH SELF-SUSTAINING HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF SALMONIDS IN CALIFORNIA. APPROXIMATELY 62% OF THE REQUESTED PACIFIC COASTAL SALMON RECOVERY FUND (PCSRF) AND INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT AND JOBS ACT (IIJA) FUNDS WILL TARGET PRIORITY 1 PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS FACTORS LIMITING THE PRODUCTIVITY OF ESA-LISTED PACIFIC SALMONIDS AS SPECIFIED IN APPROVED FEDERAL AND STATE RECOVERY PLANS

PROJECT GOAL IS REARING A PORTION (100250K) OF THE TOTAL ANNUAL SUMMER CHINOOK PRODUCTION (1M) TO YEARLING SIZE IS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE ADULT RETURN RATES, THEREBY ENHANCING OUR ABILITY TO COLLECT LOCAL BROODSTOCK WITH THE EVENTUAL GOAL OF ALLOWING THIS PROGRAM TO BECOME INDEPENDENT OF OUT OF BASIN BROOD SOURCE, AND PROVIDE QUALITY PREY ITEMS FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES. THE YEARLING PRODUCTION WILL BE IMPLEMENTED INITIALLY AT AN EXPERIMENTAL LEVEL. IF SUCCESSFUL, A GREATER PROPORTION OF SUBYEARLING PRODUCTION WILL BE TRANSITIONED TO A YEARLING PROGRAM IF RISK/BENEFIT DATA INDICATES THIS MANAGEMENT STRATEGY IS SUCCESSFUL.

THIS PROPOSAL IS TO PRODUCE 500,000 JUVENILE SPRING CHINOOK SALMON AT DWORSHAK NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY (NFH) TO SUPPORT THE SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES. WITH FUNDING FROM THIS PROPOSAL SPRING CHINOOK SALMON EGGS THAT WERE SPAWNED FROM ADULTS COLLECTED IN AUGUST, 2021 WILL BE INCUBATED AND THEN JUVENILES REARED UNTIL THE SMOLT STAGE IN APRIL, 2023. THIS PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR FISH FOOD, CHEMICALS AND SUPPLIES, FISH HEALTH, MARKING AND TAGGING, LABOR TO CARE FOR THE FISH, AND POND RENTAL AT DWORSHAK NFH.

WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (WDFW) IS REQUIRED BY STATE LAW (RCW 77.95.290) TO MASS MARK (ADIPOSE FIN CLIP) ALL HATCHERY CHINOOK AND COHO DESTINED FOR HARVEST TO MAINTAIN THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE COMMERCIAL, TRIBAL, AND RECREATIONAL SALMON FISHERIES WHILE PROTECTING NATIVE SALMONID RUNS. FUNDING IS REQUIRED TO REPLACE A PORTION OF MASS MARKING MANUAL TRAILERS WITH A MORE EFFICIENT METHOD TO ENSURE THAT ALL FISH INTENDED FOR HARVEST ARE MASS MARKED. THE DEPARTMENT MASS MARKS (ADIPOSE FIN CLIPS) APPROXIMATELY 100 MILLION HATCHERY PRODUCED SALMON AND STEELHEAD ANNUALLY.  WDFW IS FINDING IT INCREASINGLY DIFFICULT TO STAFF MANUAL MARKING TRAILERS.  THE DEPARTMENT HAS BEEN STRUGGLING TO GET ALL THE FISH WE ARE LEGALLY OBLIGATED TO MASS MARK COMPLETED EACH YEAR.  IN ADDITION, THERE IS A PROPOSED 20 MILLION ADDITIONAL INCREASE IN PRODUCTION TO PRODUCE MORE HATCHERY FISH FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT ORCAS WHICH WILL COMPOUND THIS ISSUE. UTILIZING AN AUTOFISH SYSTEM TO SUPPLEMENT OUR MANU

THE RCO WILL ACT AS A PASSTHROUGH FOR 2 PROJECTS UNDER THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY HATCHERY PREY PROGRAM. THE PROJECTS ARE LISTED BELOW:  1) TULALIP TRIBES HATCHERY: TULALIP HATCHERY SUBYEARLING SUMMER CHINOOK PRODUCTION FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES BY UP TO 2.0 MILLION IN BROODYEAR 2022 (2.4M INCREASED TO 4.4M RELEASE), CONTINGENT ON RETURNING BROODSTOCK AVAILABILITY, AND DEVELOP DESIGN PLANS TO MORE EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY CAPTURE AND HOLD ADULT RETURNS AND RELEASE JUVENILES AT THE LOWER TULALIP CREEK PONDS, WHICH IS THE TRIBES' ADULT RETURN AND JUVENILE RELEASE FACILITY. 2) MUCKLESHOOT INDIAN TRIBE HATCHERY: THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO COMPLETE THE REPAIRS AND UPGRADES TO THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON REARING POND THAT ARE NEEDED TO RETURN IT TO WORKING CONDITION. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON THE TRIBE WILL USE THE FUNDS TO REFURBISH THE SALMON REARING POND AND OPERATE THE REARING POND TO ACCLIMATE 180,000 CHINOOK SALMON IN ORDER TO INCREASE FOOD AVAI

THE PROPOSED ACTION IN THE BIOLOGICAL OPINION INCLUDES FUNDING FOR DISCRETE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS TARGETED AT INCREASING THE PRODUCTIVITY AND ABUNDANCE OF SEVERAL DEPRESSED SALMON POPULATIONS WITHIN PUGET SOUND. UP TO $8,869,456 IS AVAILABLE FOR PUGET SOUND HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS IN 2022. FOR THE 2019-2028 AGREEMENT, AVAILABLE FUNDING IS DIRECTED AT HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE NORTHERN BOUNDARY WATERSHEDS OF NOOKSACK, SKAGIT, STILLAGUAMISH, SNOHOMISH, DUNGENESS, AND MID-HOOD CANAL (DOSEWALLIPS, HAMMA, AND DUCKABUSH) OVER THREE YEARS. MORE BROADLY, IMPROVEMENTS IN WATERSHED SALMON HABITAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO RECOVERY OF ESA-LISTED PUGET SOUND CHINOOK SALMON, INCREASE PREY ABUNDANCE FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES, AND SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PUGET SOUND CHINOOK FISHERIES RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN.

THIS PROPOSED BUDGET IDENTIFIES FUNDING ALLOTMENTS FOR ANNUAL OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE (O&M) OF THREE SALMON HATCHERIES ( BONNEVILLE, OXBOW/HERMAN CREEK PONDS, AND UMATILLA AS AUTHORIZED BY THE MITCHELL ACT. THIS FUNDING IS PROVIDED BY NOAA FISHERIES ON AN ANNUAL BASIS AND COVERS NOT ONLY THE O&M SPECIFICALLY RELATING TO THESE HATCHERIES AS DETAILED IN THE BUDGET, BUT OTHER SPECIFIC TASKS (PATHOLOGY SERVICES, FISH ID AND FISH DISTRIBUTION) THAT DIRECTLY RELATE TO THE O&M OF THESE HATCHERIES. ANNUAL PRODUCTION FROM THESE FOUR THREE HATCHERIES TO PROVIDE PREY SUPPLEMENTATION FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES IS APPROXIMATELY 1.87 MILLION FISH.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO FILL IN GAPS IN ESTIMATED CATCH FOR NORTH OF FALCON TROLL FISHERIES LOCATIONS USING PROXY METHODS AS DESCRIBED IN PACIFIC SALMON COMMISSION REPORT NO. 46. REVIEW OF INDIRECT METHODS USED IN ESTIMATION OF CHINOOK SALMON EXPLOITATION RATES AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVEMENT. THIS PROPOSAL WILL ADDRESS THE C2R PROGRAM INTENTS: 1.      DEVELOP ANALYTICAL TOOLS THAT INVOLVE CATCH AND ESCAPEMENT DATA IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CHINOOK CHAPTER; AND 2.      PROVIDE TIMELY DATA TO IMPLEMENT THE CHINOOK CHAPTER VIA IMPROVEMENTS AND STUDIES DESIGNED TO ACHIEVE CTC AND CWT WORKGROUP DATA STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES.

THE CURRENT ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATION METHOD FOR GRAYS HARBOR FALL CHINOOK RELIES ON REDD COUNTS IN INDEX AREAS AND SUPPLEMENTAL SURVEYS, YET ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES FOR THIS STOCK DO NOT MEET PACIFIC SALMON COMMISSION (PSC) CHINOOK TECHNICAL COMMITTEE (CTC) ASSESSMENT STANDARDS. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL ADDRESS U.S. SECTION PRIORITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO VERIFY OR RECALIBRATE THE ESTIMATED ESCAPEMENT OF FALL CHINOOK BY COMPARING THE CURRENT APPROACH WITH THREE ALTERNATIVE APPROACHES IN THE NEWAUKUM RIVER, A TRIBUTARY OF THE CHEHALIS RIVER THAT IS ALREADY THE FOCUS OF INTENSIVE MONITORING. THE NEW ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES WILL BE GENERATED FROM: 1) REDD COUNTS ACROSS THE ENTIRE SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION, 2) TRANSGENERATIONAL GENETIC MARK RECAPTURE (TGMR), AND 3) ADULT CARCASS MARK-RECAPTURE (CMR). ALL THREE APPROACHES IMPROVE UPON THE CURRENT METHOD BY ADDRESSING ASSUMPTIONS (E.G., REDDS ARE CORRECTLY IDENTIFIED TO SPECIES, SURVEY REACHES PROVIDE REPRESENTATION OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION O

THE PROJECT DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL STRIVES TO IMPROVE ODFWS ABILITY TO PROVIDE TIMELY, CONSISTENT AND RELIABLE ESTIMATES OF HARVEST FOR THE UMPQUA RIVER, AN ESCAPEMENT INDICATOR STOCK FOR THE MID-OREGON COAST (MOC) AGGREGATE. THESE METRICS WILL ENABLE ODFW TO REPORT ON CYER FOR THIS RETURN YEAR WITH ACCURACY AND PRECISION AND HELP THE AGENCY TO MORE CLOSELY MONITOR COASTAL FISHERIES WHICH MAY HAVE INDETERMINATE DIFFERENTIAL IMPACTS ON THE ESCAPEMENT INDICATOR STOCK COMPONENT (S. UMPQUA), WHEN COMPARED TO FISHERIES AND THEIR OPERATION ON THE GREATER POPULATION OF THE UMPQUA RIVER BASIN. IN THE CURRENT TERMINAL AREA, ADJUSTMENT DATA IS NEEDED TO CONSTRUCT CYERS FOR OUR MOC INDICATOR BASINS AND VALIDATION OF THE HISTORICAL HARVEST CARD SYSTEM IS NEEDED TO ENSURE THAT THIS FISHERY HAS BEEN DEPICTED ACCURATELY IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF THOSE NEEDED CYER ESTIMATES. THE E-CREEL WOULD PROVIDE FOR AN INDEPENDENT ESTIMATOR TO COMPARE TO THOSE CURRENT DETERMINISTIC ESTIMATES USED FOR THE EVALUA

THE BIOLOGICAL OPINION (BIOP) ASSOCIATED WITH THE 20192028 UPDATE TO THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY (NMFS CONSULTATION WCR201810660) IDENTIFIED A FUNDING INITIATIVE TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF HARVEST AND OTHER LIMITING FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTED TO THE REDUCED STATUS OF PUGET SOUND CHINOOK SALMON.   THE BIOP STATES: "THE PROPOSED FUNDING INITIATIVE HAS THREE ELEMENTS. FOR PUGET SOUND CHINOOK SALMON, THE INITIATIVE IS TARGETED AT THE WEAKEST POPULATIONS THAT ARE CONSIDERED ESSENTIAL FOR RECOVERY AND THOSE MOST AFFECTED BY NORTHERN FISHERIES. THESE INCLUDE THE NOOKSACK, DUNGENESS, STILLAGUAMISH, AND MID-HOOD CANAL POPULATIONS. THE FUNDING IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT CONTINUATION OF CONSERVATION HATCHERY PROGRAMS THAT ARE ALREADY IN PLACE ON THE NOOKSACK, DUNGENESS, AND STILLAGUAMISH RIVERS AND A NEW PROGRAM FOR THE MID-HOOD CANAL POPULATION."  THE PROJECTS OUTLINED IN THIS APPLICATION IMPLEMENT THE HATCHERY CONSERVATION PROGRAMS IN THE NOOKSACK AND DUNGENESS RIVERS.

WDFW WILL IMPLEMENT PROVISIONS OF THE UPDATED 20192028 PACIFIC SALMON TREATY (PST) AND THE ASSOCIATED BIOLOGICAL OPINION (NMFS CONSULTATION WCR201810660). THE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: STOCK AND FISHERY MONITORING. APPLICATION OF CODED WIRE TAGS (CWT), ACOUSTIC TAGS, AND OTOLITH MARKS, SAMPLING PUGET SOUND FISHERIES FOR CWTS, RECOVERY AND DECODING OF THE TAGS AND OTOLITHS, AND DATA ENTRY AND ANALYSIS FOR THE COASTWIDE REGIONAL MARK INFORMATION SYSTEM DATABASE, WHICH IS SHARED AMONG MULTIPLE STATE, FEDERAL, AND CANADIAN FISHERIES MANAGERS. GENETIC SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS FOR STOCK DIFFERENTIATION IN MIXED FISHERIES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF ABUNDANCE, SURVIVAL, AND PRODUCTIVITY ESTIMATES. TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THE PACIFIC SALMON COMMISSION. THIS INCLUDES REPRESENTATION ON THE CHINOOK, COHO, CHUM AND FRASER (SOCKEYE) TECHNICAL COMMITTEES. STAFF PROVIDE MODELING AND STATISTICAL WORK ANALYZING FISHERYRELATED DATA TO ASSIST THE COMMISSION IN THE MANAGEMENT OF TRANSBOUNDARY FISHERIES. HA

IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY REQUIRES SIGNIFICANT ALLOCATION OF THE AGENCY'S MANAGEMENT, TECHNICAL ASSESSMENT STAFFS AND ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT PERSONNEL IN ORDER TO COMPLY WITH TREATY PROVISIONS. THESE ODFW REPRESENTATIVES MUST PROVIDE INTER/INTRA-AGENCY COORDINATION AND CONSULTATION WITH OTHER PST/PSC ENTITIES AND THEIR MEMBERS TO ENSURE FULL PARTICIPATION IN THE COMMISSION PANELS, ITS TECHNICAL COMMITTEES, AND MANAGEMENT PROCESSES. FUNDING PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR ODFW SOUTHERN PANEL MEMBERS AND THEIR ALTERNATES WHEN THESE PERSONNEL ARE PREPARING FOR - AND ARE ACTIVE IN - THE PACIFIC SALMON COMMISSION (PSC) PROCESS.  FUNDING PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR ODFW TO DEVELOP ITS CHINOOK SALMON INDICATOR STOCK PROGRAM, COORDINATE FIELD OPERATIONS AND TECHNICAL ACTIVITIES AND PROVIDE DATA EXCHANGE SERVICES, AS REQUIRED UNDER PROVISIONS OF THE TREATY.  FUNDING ALLOWS ODFW TO IMPLEMENT CHINOOK SALMON INDICATOR STOCK TAGGING, TAG RECOVERY AND CODED WIRE TAG (CWT) IDENTIFICATION OPERATION

PACIFIC SALMON TREATY FY22 PROGRAM IN SUPPORT OF THE BELOW PROJECTS:  1) NORTHERN OREGON COAST AGGREGATE ABUNDANCE AND ESCAPEMENT INDICATOR ESTIMATES: NEHALEM, NESTUCCA AND SILETZ RIVERS 2) OREGON CODED WIRE TAG SAMPLING OF LOWER COLUMBIA AND WILLAMETTE RIVERS RECREATIONAL AND LOWER COLUMBIA RIVER COMMERCIAL FISHERIES 3) ESTIMATING OF SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT IN THE SOUTH UMPQUA RIVER BASIN 4) NORTHERN OREGON COAST ESCAPEMENT INDICATOR HARVEST ESTIMATES: SIUSLAW, SILETZ AND NEHALEM RIVERS 5) FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON SCALE AGE COMPOSITION ANALYSIS FOR OREGON COASTAL STOCKS 6) AGE DATABASE FOR CHINOOK SALMON

PACIFIC SALMON TREATY FY22 PROGRAM IN SUPPORT OF THE BELOW PROJECTS:   SUB-PROJECT 1. OREGON OCEAN SAMPLING FOR CODED WIRE TAGS IN COMMERCIAL TROLL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES  OBJECTIVE 1.1. MAINTAIN FULL ELECTRONIC SAMPLING FOR CWTS OF CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON ON ALL OCEAN RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL TROLL SALMON VESSELS THAT ARE SAMPLED. PRIOR TO 2011, SAMPLING USED ELECTRONIC SAMPLING TO VERIFY THE PRESENCE/ABSENCE OF CWTS ONLY IN ADIPOSE FIN MARKED SALMON. INCREASED RELEASES OF TAGGED SALMON WITHOUT ASSOCIATED ADIPOSE FIN MARKS HAVE RESULTED IN A DISCONNECT BETWEEN CWT TAGGING ACTIVITIES AND OCEAN CWT SAMPLING. PENDING PST CWT PROGRAM SUPPORT, THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE FULL ELECTRONIC SAMPLING OF EVERY CHINOOK SALMON ON SAMPLED RECREATIONAL BOATS FROM THE OCEAN SALMON FISHERY, AS WELL AS ON SAMPLED COMMERCIAL TROLL SALMON VESSELS. OBJECTIVE 1.2. MEET OR EXCEED THE 20% SAMPLING RATE FOR CWTS FROM CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON FROM THE OCEAN RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL TROL

THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY SOUTH FORK NOOKSACK CHINOOK HATCHERY CONSERVATION PROGRAM SUPPORTS PROJECTS: 1) HATCHERY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE IN SKOOKUM CREEK HATCHERY. 2) SOUTH FORK CHINOOK MONITORING AND EVALUATION. PROJECTS ARE RELATED TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SOUTH FORK HATCHERY CONSERVATION PROGRAM.

THIS PROPOSAL PROVIDES FOR DOCKSIDE MONITORING OF THE NON-TRIBAL OCEAN COMMERCIAL SALMON TROLL FISHERIES AND OCEAN RECREATIONAL SALMON FISHERIES OCCURRING OFF THE COAST OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON.  THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF DOCKSIDE MONITORING ARE: 1)      COLLECT CATCH AND EFFORT DATA SUFFICIENT TO GENERATE IN-SEASON AND POST-SEASON ESTIMATES OF TOTAL CATCH, RELEASED FISH (RECREATIONAL ONLY), AND EFFORT FOR ALL RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES WITH COEFFICIENTS OF VARIATION (CVS) OF 10% OR LESS ON COMMONLY OBSERVED SPECIES. IN-SEASON CATCH ESTIMATES WILL BE PRODUCED FOR ALL QUOTA FISHERIES ON A WEEKLY (OR MORE FREQUENT) BASIS TO ALLOW FOR IN-SEASON MANAGEMENT; THE PERIODS FOR POST-SEASON FINAL CATCH ESTIMATES WILL BE STATISTICAL WEEK PERIODS FOR ALL SALMON FISHERIES AND STATISTICAL MONTH PERIODS FOR NON-QUOTA FISHERIES.  2)      EXAMINE, USING ELECTRONIC DETECTION DEVICES, A MINIMUM OF 20% OF THE LANDED CATCH OF CHINOOK AND COHO (BOTH MARKED AND UNMARKED) FROM THE SPORT AND C

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS THIS PROPOSAL IS TO ENTER 2022 RETURN YEAR PUGET SOUND AND COASTAL WASHINGTON CHINOOK SALMON SCALE AGES, CODED WIRE TAG RECOVERY INFORMATION, AND BIOLOGICAL DATA INTO A CENTRALIZED AGE DATABASE IN SEASON TO STREAMLINE ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES, RUN RECONSTRUCTION, AND FORECASTS FOR SEVERAL INDICATOR STOCKS.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS TRANS-GENERATIONAL GENETIC MARK-RECAPTURE (TGMR) PROJECT IS TO: 1) ESTIMATE THE ABUNDANCE OF CHINOOK SALMON SPAWNERS (N) AND EFFECTIVE BREEDERS (NB) IN THE STILLAGUAMISH RIVER ABOVE THE SMOLT TRAP SITE (RM 6) USING GENETIC ABUNDANCE METHODS FOR BROOD YEAR 2022.  THE SECONDARY OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO: 2) ESTIMATE THE NATURAL SPAWNING CHINOOK SALMON ABUNDANCE BY ORIGIN (HATCHERY OR NATURAL), SEX AND AGE, AND 3) TO REFINE THE REDD-COUNT EXPANSION CALIBRATION FACTOR DEVELOPED FROM HISTORIC REDD-BASED ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES.

THE PRIMARY PROJECT OBJECTIVES OF THE SOUTH FORK STILLAGUAMISH FALL CHINOOK NATURAL STOCK RESTORATION PROGRAM ARE TO 1)SEINE UP TO 900 WILD JUVENILE CHINOOK FRY FROM GRAVEL BARS ON THE SOUTH FORK STILLAGUAMISH AND ITS TRIBUTARIES (WHEN RIVER TEMPERATURES ARE SUITABLE, IN EARLY SPRING) AND TRANSPORT TO THE TRIBE'S HATCHERY. 2) SAMPLE JUVENILES FOR TISSUE TO DETERMINE POPULATION ASSIGNMENT WITH A GOAL OF RETAINING 450 FALL ASSIGNED JUVENILES. 3) REAR FALL-ASSIGNED JUVENILES TO SPAWNING ADULTS, WITH AN OBSERVED 60% FRY TO ADULT SURVIVAL RATE. RATES OF MATURATION VARY ACROSS BROOD YEARS WITH FISH BECOMING MATURE BETWEEN ONE AND FIVE YEARS OF BEING HELD IN CAPTIVITY. 4) SPAWN MATURE ADULTS AND REAR THEIR OFFSPRING FOR 6 TO 8 MONTHS. 5) RELEASE 200,000 AGE ZERO SMOLTS INTO THE SOUTH FORK STILLAGUAMISH EACH SPRING. 6) COLLECT ADULT BROODSTOCK FROM THE NORTH FORK STILLAGUAMISH AS PART OF THE SUMMER SUPPLEMENTATION PROGRAM. THIS PROVIDES A SUPPLEMENTAL SOURCE OF GAMETES IN CASE ADULT

GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE SEAK CHINOOK SALMON FISHERY MITIGATION PROGRAM ARE TO MITIGATE ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF 7.5% HARVEST REDUCTIONS BY INCREASING PRODUCTION OF AND ACCESS TO HATCHERY-PRODUCED SALMON IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA. PRIMARY IMPACTS OF THE CHINOOK SALMON HARVEST REDUCTION ARE ON SEAK "HOOK AND LINE FISHERIES," WHICH INCLUDE COMMERCIAL TROLL, SPORT FISH, AND ASSOCIATED INTERESTS. THE PRIMARY GOAL IS TO OFFSET, TO THE EXTENT THAT FUNDING ALLOWS, THE LOST SPRING AND EARLY SUMMER CHINOOK OPPORTUNITY FROM REDUCTIONS IN THE DIRECTED SPORT AND COMMERCIAL HARVEST OF CHINOOK SALMON RESULTING FROM THE 2019 PST AGREEMENT. FY22 HATCHERY ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS THROUGH THIS GRANT ARE:  1.      SAWMILL CREEK HATCHERY EXPANSION: PHASE VI, SUBPHASE 1  $2,408,272 2.      WHITMAN LAKE HATCHERY REARING CAPACITY INCREASE: PHASE III  $1,001,830 3.      MAINTAIN SOUTHERN SOUTHEAST CHINOOK PRODUCTION  $575,900 4.      CHATHAM PREDATOR STUDY  $225,000

PACIFIC SALMON TREATY FY22 PROGRAM IN SUPPORT OF THE BELOW PROJECTS:   THE OBJECTIVES FOR ASSESSMENT OF THE CHILKAT RIVER STOCK OF CHINOOK SALMON ARE: 1. TO ESTIMATE THE INRIVER ABUNDANCE OF LARGE (=AGE1.3) CHINOOK SALMON IN THE CHILKAT RIVER DRAINAGE, SO THAT THE ESTIMATE IS WITHIN 25% OF THE TRUE VALUE 90% OF THE TIME. 2. TO ESTIMATE THE AGE AND SEX PROPORTIONS OF THE INRIVER RUN OF LARGE CHINOOK SALMON IN THE CHILKAT RIVER, SO THAT THE ESTIMATES ARE WITHIN 10% OF THE TRUE VALUES 90% OF THE TIME. 3. TO ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF CHINOOK SALMON SMOLT EMIGRATING FROM THE CHILKAT RIVER IN SPRING 2023, SO THAT THE ESTIMATE IS WITHIN 40% OF THE TRUE VALUE 90% OF THE TIME. 4. TO ESTIMATE THE MARINE HARVEST OF CHINOOK SALMON FROM THE 2021 BROOD YEAR IN 2024-2028 SUCH THAT THE ESTIMATE IS WITHIN 30% OF THE TRUE VALUE 90% OF THE TIME.  PROJECT 2 OBJECTIVES:  1. TO PURCHASE THREE PC-BASED RUGGEDIZED TABLET COMPUTERS FOR COMMERCIAL AND FIELD PROJECT DATA COLLECTION FROM CHINOOK SALMON HAR

PACIFIC SALMON TREATY CODED WIRE TAG FUNDS PROVIDED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO MAINTAIN OR INCREASE CODED WIRE TAG SAMPLING RATES FOR CHINOOK SALMON CAUGHT IN COMMERCIAL FISHERIES IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA AT AN OBJECTIVE OF 20% OR MORE EACH STATISTICAL WEEK, GEAR, AND STRATA. PERSONNEL FUNDING THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO WORK TO INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY OF CODED WIRE TAG RECOVERY THROUGH THE USE OF HANDHELD TAG DETECTION WANDS TO IDENTIFY CHINOOK SALMON WITH ADIPOSE FIN CLIPS THAT DO NOT CONTAIN CODED WIRE TAGS. MATCHED SCALE AND TISSUE SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM COMMERCIAL HARVESTED CHINOOK SALMON IN THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA TROLL AND SELECT NET FISHERIES.

PACIFIC SALMON TREATY FUNDS REQUESTED UNDER THIS APPLICATION SUPPORT THREE ACTIVITIES NECESSARY TO SUPPORT THE UNITED STATES PARTICIPATION IN THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY. TASK 1 ($157,486) SUPPORTS IDAHO FISH AND GAME PERSONNEL PARTICIPATING IN AND COORDINATING FISHERY RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WITH THE COMMISSION, FEDERAL, STATE, AND TRIBAL FISHERY AGENCIES. TASK 2 ($99,301) SUPPORTS CODED WIRE TAGGING (CWT) OF CHINOOK SALMON STOCKS REARED IN IDAHO TO ESTIMATE FISHERY HARVEST RATES. TASK 3 ($46,488) SUPPORTS LONG-TERM ESTIMATION OF THE SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT OF CHINOOK SALMON IN IDAHO BY AERIAL COUNTING OF SALMON REDDS.

THE MAKAH TRIBE REQUESTS FUNDING TO SUPPORT AND IMPROVE ITS CODED-WIRE TAG SAMPLING PROGRAM. SPECIFICALLY, THE TRIBE PROPOSES TO CONTINUE THE EMPLOYMENT OF AN ADDITIONAL SAMPLER FOR THE 2022-2023 SALMON FISHING SEASON, AS WELL AS TO SUPPORT THE WAGES OF THE PRIMARY SAMPLER AND TAG READER. THE TRIBE ALSO PROPOSES ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR VARIOUS EXPENDABLE SUPPLIES AND PURCHASE OF A NEW CODED WIRE TAG DETECTION WAND.

TOGETHER WITH STATE MATCHING FUNDS, WASHINGTONS PCSRF AWARD WILL FUND PROJECTS AND ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN NOAA-APPROVED RECOVERY PLANS AND THAT UPHOLD TREATY RIGHTS. THE 86 HIGH-PRIORITY, SITE-BASED PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS LIMITING FACTORS AND PROTECT OR RESTORE HABITAT STATEWIDE. HATCHERY AND HARVEST REFORM ACTIONS WILL COMPLEMENT THE HABITAT PROJECTS BY IMPROVING FITNESS OF WILD FISH AND ADDRESSING HATCHERY OPERATIONS THAT LIMIT THE PRODUCTIVITY OF LISTED POPULATIONS AND NON-LISTED POPULATIONS ESSENTIAL FOR EXERCISE OF TRIBAL TREATY RIGHTS. WASHINGTONS ESTABLISHED MULTI-TIERED MONITORING PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SALMON HABITAT PROJECTS AND MEASURE PROGRESS TOWARD RECOVERY. MONITORING OUTCOMES INCLUDE DATA AND FINDINGS THAT HELP DETERMINE IF FUNDS ARE WELL-INVESTED, PRODUCE DESIRED RESULTS, AND SUPPORT WASHINGTONS ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH.

THE PROPOSED ACTION IN THE BIOLOGICAL OPINION INCLUDES FUNDING FOR DISCRETE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS TARGETED AT INCREASING THE PRODUCTIVITY AND ABUNDANCE OF SEVERAL DEPRESSED SALMON POPULATIONS WITHIN PUGET SOUND. UP TO $8,869,456 IS AVAILABLE FOR PUGET SOUND HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS IN 2021. FOR THE 2019-2028 AGREEMENT, AVAILABLE FUNDING IS DIRECTED AT HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS WITHIN THE NORTHERN BOUNDARY WATERSHEDS OF NOOKSACK, SKAGIT, STILLAGUAMISH, SNOHOMISH, DUNGENESS, AND MID-HOOD CANAL (DOSEWALLIPS, HAMMA HAMMA, AND DUCKABUSH) OVER THREE YEARS. MORE BROADLY, IMPROVEMENTS IN WATERSHED SALMON HABITAT WOULD CONTRIBUTE TO RECOVERY OF ESA-LISTED PUGET SOUND CHINOOK SALMON, PREY ABUNDANCE FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PUGET SOUND CHINOOK FISHERIES RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN.
